founder_quote: "We are always looking out for suppliers who offer that "something a little bit different" that is affordable without compromising on quality."

name: The Mantique
description: Located in Winchester, The Mantique presents an ever-evolving edit for the style-savvy gentleman which is curated by owner Liz. Showcasing a mix of premium British brands and designers, the boutique places quality, design and function at the fore. Its sophisticated and stylish product range includes apparel, grooming products and travel accessories and appeals to men of all types, from the commuter to the adventurer.

name: PORTER + cole
description: Having worked in luxury retail and executive management for a combined total of twenty years, Billee and Ronnie made the decision to found Porter + Cole on Manchester's High Street. The shop was named after their two dogs, and was envisaged as 360° lifestyle space where shoppers could discover design-led goods over delicious food and great conversation.
founder_quote: Our collection is sourced globally, and we spend a lot of time ensuring that there’s a continuity of style and design in everything we present.

name: Plain Bear
description: Starting life as a stall in Greenwich Market Plain Bear, founded by Frank Whitford, is now permanently located in a shop within Deptford Market. Frank was attracted to the area when he realised that he’d be part of a community project supporting local businesses. With a background in art, his interest in the subject of simplicity is apparent in his own-brand clothing where simplified graphics and bold shapes feature. Sourcing clothing and accessories from other brands to sit alongside his own, Frank expertly curates products for the contemporary wardrobe.
founder_quote: "I hope and believe that the high street will evolve, with a stronger element of locality; allowing small businesses to flourish and the concept of community to be regained."

name: Creighton’s Chocolaterie
description: Based in an old bakery in Leighton Buzzard, Creighton's Chocolaterie is run by mother and daughter duo Andrea Huntington and Lucy Elliott. As Andrea is a trained chocolatier and Lucy a graphic designer, the pair decided to open a boutique which combined delicious flavours with eye-catching designs. All of their products are created on site behind the retail space and the colourful collection includes both traditional and experimental flavour combinations
founder_quote: "I believe everyone wants a more personalised shopping experience and customers are on the look out for the new and inspiring."

description: As the name suggests, Forest in Dulwich is home to an abundance of unusual house plants, small succulents and prickly cacti sourced by mother-daughter duo Fran and Alice Bailey. Continuing a legacy of floristry started by Fran's father who was a grower in Holland, Fran went on to study floristry before opening their first shop The Fresh Flower Company in Dulwich over 12 years ago. Since then their business has literally bloomed and now includes Forest, which is their second shop.
founder_quote: "Whilst online shopping is growing at an enormous rate, I think more and more people are becoming passionate about supporting local, independent businesses and finding destination spots where they can combine the enjoyment of shopping with eating and drinking."
name: Forest
A New Tribe
description: East London's A New Tribe offers eclectic selection of beautiful interior objects and textiles sourced from independent designers and small brands from around the world. Founder Ella Jones ensures every object is carefully considered - not only for its beauty, but also for the ethos and care that has gone into each item and brand. The offering includes unique products from Morocco, Japan, India, the UK and the USA - either hand-made or small batch production. A New Tribe is also home to 'The Rug Trade', with an extensive selection of Boucherouite, Azilal, and Beni Ourain Moroccan Rugs including rare vintage finds and newly designed rugs hand-made using the traditional techniques in Morocco.
founder_quote: "I love having a shop on Chatsworth Road, it has a real mix of people and a community feel, as well as other great independent shops. East London is endlessly creative and has a talent for producing and nurturing talented designers, makers and artists, many of whom I work with."

name: Curiouser & Curiouser
description: With a vision to sell beautiful things made by creative people, Curiouser & Curiouser opened its doors in 2010 and is now based in two locations across Edinburgh. Founded by husband and wife duo Laura and Ian, the boutique showcases the best of British and Scandinavian design, from illustrative prints, jewellery and homewares, working with the creative Edinburgh community to discover artists and designers. As well as sourcing, Laura and Ian also employ five illustrators and print makers as well as a photographer to keep their product and both boutiques constantly creative.
founder_quote: "We feel so fortunate to live in Edinburgh, it's a fantastic city on so many levels. You are never far from a historical site, green spaces or a great eatery. We are always taken aback by the beauty and sense of community the city has to offer, although it often feels more like a small town than a city as you can always find someone you have in common."

name: The Modern Botanist
description: Filled with a colourful array of flowers and botanical inspired homewares, The Modern Botanist is located in Plaxtol in Sevenoaks and is run by mother-daughter duo Claire and Charlotte. An interior stylist and a florist, the pair opened the doors of The Modern Botanist to showcase the beauty of plants and the quality of UK craftsmanship. Their range includes floral candles, vintage accessories, plant pots and home accessories and customers are invited into the space to attend workshops where they can learn new skills to share with friends and family.

name: Elkins
founder_quote: It's been so encouraging to see how much our customers love the products we stock, which means all the research and hard work into sourcing these brands has really paid off.
description: Trained designer Jessamy Llewellyn started her career making and selling printed homewares at various London markets. Little by little, she developed an interest in opening her own bricks-and-mortar shop where she could showcase the inspiring brands she had discovered throughout the years. In September 2017 she took the plunge and opened Elkins in Crystal Palace, where she stocks a carefully curated selection of homewares, clothing, jewellery and gifts.

name: The Wee Store
description: When boutique owner Lucie met childrenswear buyer Charlie, she knew she'd found the perfect business partner. The two mothers run The Wee Store, a bright and cheery kids' boutique in Hove. Their expertly curated range is filled with cleverly designed products that are sure to delight children and parents alike.
founder_quote: We have noticed a recent shift in attitude, with more people understanding that if they don't support their local small businesses then the high street simply won't exist. We're very optimistic!

name: Blink
description: Located in Falmouth, Blink offers an ever-evolving showcase of design and fashion, curated by founders Norbert and Sarah. The boutique celebrates lesser-known designers and places them alongside classic brands that have stood the test of time, creating a truly unique edit. The pair hope to inspire and delight customers through their range of products and invest in pieces that are both accessible and affordable.
founder_quote: “Despite the growing trend towards online retail, we believe that there will always be a desire for bricks and mortar shops where people can have a quality shopping experience that offers community as well as indulgence.”

name: Snapdragon
description: Snapdragon Edinburgh is a botanical boutique based in the thriving Bruntsfield area of the city. Founder Catherine Traynor opened the shop in 2014 as a space to sell natural, British garden style florals and flower-inspired fragranced candles. Snapdragon's products are curated with one simple philosophy in mind - to provide shoppers with naturally elegant and understated items for their homes.
founder_quote: We predict an increased interest from consumers in the stories behind what is being bought, and in shops where creativity and design are part of the shopping experience.

name: Cotswold Grey
description: Filled with a mix of antique, contemporary and reproduction homewares, Cotswold Grey is located in Moreton-In-Marsh and takes its name from the paint traditionally used for buildings in the region. The shop is run by Simon Jeffrey who transformed the space from an ironmongers, located at the property for over 160 years. The stunning range of furniture and home accessories caters for both the local community and the thousands of people who visit the Cotswolds each year.
founder_quote: "We are a team of like-minded interiors enthusiasts, with a passion for creating beautiful interiors and sourcing eclectic pieces for our shop."

name: Ayten Gasson
description: Launched in the summer of 2005, luxury lingerie label Ayten Gasson has become recognised in the UK not only for its beautiful collections, but also for its firm commitment in supporting the UK fashion industry. Every piece from each collection is proudly designed and made in the UK using English lace and trims.  All pieces are handmade in their Brighton boutique using traditional sewing methods.
founder_quote: “We are dedicated to sourcing the best materials for our products. Our lace, for example, comes from The Cluny Lace Company who designed and made the lace on Kate Middleton's wedding dress.”

name: We Are Rushworth
description: Having studied textiles at university, a career in fashion was a natural choice for Victoria Rushworth. After living in Paris for four years she returned to the Berwick Upon Tweed to open her studio boutique, where she sells her curated, locally-made knitwear range alongside other accessories and lifestyle products.
founder_quote: I am constantly striving to discover and be adventurous, to offer something alternative of good quality.

name: Jam Industries
description: City-meets-surf boutique Jam Industries was founded by brothers Andrew and Mark, and sits just a stone's throw away from the coast in Salcombe. After several years working as surf instructors the duo decided to go into business selling the laid-back clothes they enjoyed wearing, which resulted in the shop's signature "English beach" style.
founder_quote: We started Jam a few years back when working at Lyndon Wake surf school in North Devon. We wanted to build a British beach brand that can travel in the same way its customers do.

description: Founded by partners Paul and Chris in Berkhamsted, Hertfordshire, White Mint is home to a collection of homewares blending Scandinavian simplicity with the colourful and kitsch; the result is a distinctive mix of products to suit varied tastes. Since Paul was a child he dreamt of owning a shop which became a reality with the support of his partner Chris.
name: White Mint
founder_quote: "We have been a couple since 2011 and after many discussions about if we were brave enough, we finally quit the 9-5 and launched White Mint. We would rather our customers get the right thing rather than just any thing and this is a value we hold really dear to our business."

Rachel launches her flagship boutique atelier in July 2015. The boutique situated in the heart of Shoreditch, East London was formerly known as Thor & Wistle. The Rachel Entwistle Studio is based here and the full range of RE designs as well as one off pieces are exhibited in the space.
name: Rachel Entwistle
description:
Multi award winning jewellery designer Rachel Entwistle creates luxurious narrative jewellery infused with significance and meaning. Inspired by culture, symbolism and the arcane, the designs connect the wearer to something intangible and timeless and yet grounded in a deep sense of history.

Drawing on ancient concepts of amulets, talismans and protective symbolism, whilst embodying the urban culture of her East London surroundings, Rachel creates distinctive, beautifully made and covetable designs for a modern tribe.


Each piece is crafted by hand in her Shoreditch based studio using a combination of modern technology and traditional craftsmanship - the team work like modern day alchemists turning metal into magical designs. Rachel works with precious metals, bronze and gem stones and uses ethically sourced and recycled materials where possible.

founder_quote: "I love nothing better than getting out there and exploring, looking for the next trend or product. Meeting makers and stocking the right collection of local products is really rewarding, especially when you can see their brands grow and expand."
description: After a decade in London and a career in marketing and design, boutique owner Gina Pittendreigh made the move up north to pursue a new challenge. When the opportunity to take over existing boutique Radstudio in Saltaire came up, she knew this was the challenge she was after and decided to continue to grow the business. Located in a World Heritage site, the boutique itself is a destination for beautiful design-led homewares and lifestyle products.
name: Radstudio
Dassie Artisan
description: David and Roxi Zeeman opened Dassie Artisan in 2012 in Tunbridge Wells, Kent after moving to the UK and finding a lack of unique, handmade homewares available on the market. Combining their collective career experience as well as inspiration and knowledge gained on their global travels, they created a boutique and brand based on honesty, integrity and simply great design that inspires others to live well.

name: Peachey Boo
description: Located in Brighton, Peachey Boo is a colourful kid’s boutique founded by mother and daughter duo Lesley Goudman-Peachey and Hannah Peachey-Thacker. With a keen interest in art, the pair design a range of children’s apparel inspired by the relationship between parents and children and the fostering of knowledge. Crafted from high-quality fabrics, the pair use organic materials for all of their clothing to produce the best products possible.

name: Hilary & Flo
description: After redecorating her home in 2001, Shelley Carline realised her talent for sourcing unique and interesting products. Flash forward to 2015 and we see the launch of Hilary & Flo - Shelley's interiors and giftware boutique in Sheffield. Stocked with vibrant homewares and lifestyle accessories, the shop is a treasure trove for those seeking inspiring products.
founder_quote: "Retail is becoming more and more chain-focused, but I feel that we need the diversity and interest that independents bring to the high street."

name: Workshop
description: The intention behind Brighton's Workshop is to present carefully curated products that are both practical and simple in form and function. It is about providing home, lifestyle and fashion products that contribute to simple, uncomplicated, everyday living. The shop's co-owners, Jayson and Ryan, have bought their combined experience, in creative agencies and merchandising, to build a boutique that has clearly defined aesthetic principles and a product range to match.

name: Five and Dime
description: When founders Fran Webberley and Craig Kilmartin moved to Hertford a few years ago from their beloved East End of London, they soon missed the inspirational independents they had become used to while living in London and saw a real appetite for design and homewares in the Hertford locals. Both hailing from creative backgrounds, Fran and Craig decided to open Five & Dime, using the shop space and their wide range of products as a way of expressing themselves.
founder_quote: Bricks-and-mortar shops create a real experience to the customer; from the colours and smells to the service at the till, it's where people can view and touch the product then order online at their own convenience.

name: Watershed
description: Following several years' experience in the surf and lifestyle industries, James and Jake decided to found Watershed as a space to stock their favourite ocean-inspired classics. Over the past seven years, Watershed has become a stand-alone brand, renowned for its laid-back style. The Cornwall-based concept store stocks a handpicked range of casual essentials, from clothing and accessories to homewares.
founder_quote: Retail needs to evolve to survive. This evolution will include a more experience-led concept whereby physical stores will need to offer multiple services and product offerings.

name: The London Honey Co.
description: It all started for founder Steve Benbow in 1999 after he found himself pining for his rural Shropshire former life and decided to install honeybees on his Tower Bridge rooftop. Fast forward to 2018 and you'll find the The London Honey Co shop in a railway arch in Bermondsey, selling the finest single origin, raw honey, honeycomb, handmade 100% beeswax candles and 100% British mead. Their honeycomb is now a regular feature on the plates of chefs including Angela Hartnett, Marcus Waring and Skye Gyngell.
founder_quote: "Technology is doing great things for allowing food producers and craftspeople to connect directly with customers and tell their story. People want to know how their food was produced, by whom and that a decent portion of the money they pay gets to the producer themselves."

name: Hamerton + Jones
description: Design enthusiasts Sarah and Kali met through their daughters, and quickly realised that they shared a strong interest in unique yet practical homewares. They decided to put this passion to use, and in 2017 they opened their boutique Hamerton + Jones in the picturesque town of Goudhurst. The aim? To provide shoppers with inspiring products, from stationery and gifts to candles and kitchen tools.
founder_quote: Our philosophy is less is more, make it interesting.  As people become more discerning, retailers must help people to make good purchasing decisions.

name: Barney & Beau
description: Mother to four children, founder Mia Kowsor started Barney & Beau in Pontcanna, Cardiff, as a place to find design-led, modern products for both kids and the home. The shop is named after Mia's two youngest children and it was founded on the core values of empowering and supporting fellow women and mothers; many of the suppliers Mia chooses to work with are mothers themselves.
founder_quote: "Being independent and in charge of our own destiny is the beauty of what we offer. We strive to find innovative products that can't be found in high street chains and can adapt very quickly to changing trends, whilst being personable and attentive."

name: Lost Property of London
description: After several years working in the fashion and design industry, husband and wife duo John and Katy took the plunge and decided to open their own boutique. Lost Property of London was born, and the couple have never looked back. Located on an idyllic street in Islington, the boutique sells premium leather bags which re-imagine traditional English designs through a strikingly minimalist lens.
founder_quote: Every bag we sell is made by hand in our East London factory. This idea of local provenance is something that helps us engage with shoppers in a way that bigger brands just can't do.

name: Biscuit China
description: After several years working in digital design, graphic designer Karoline Borsch felt an urge to return to the tangible arts. She discovered a deep-seated love of ceramics and decided to turn this passion into a profession. Biscuit China, Karoline's boutique, is a veritable treasure trove of unique designs from both established and up-and-coming artisans, and a must-see for any ceramics enthusiast.
founder_quote: People still want to see expertise and craftsmanship in the products that they buy - this is why I think that small independent boutiques are going to stay relevant.

name: The Good Place
description: The Good Place in Chelsea was founded by Leona Mani as a space to showcase beautiful and ethical brands from around the world. Leona is passionate about promoting transparency in the supply chain and championing businesses that empower women, and it was from this passion that The Good Place was born.
founder_quote: I believe in using technology within the bricks-and-mortar experience, thus creating a more personal and inspiring customer journey.

name: Minerva
description: Minerva in Plymouth is a trove of design-led goods, stocking everything from streetwear-inspired men's clothing and accessories to plants and records. The store's ideology is very much rooted in street culture and contemporary urban fashion; shop owner Dan feels strongly that he should equip his customers for the rigours of modern life without sacrificing style.
founder_quote: We have something for everyone; we chop and change brands and are always trying new things to keep the store fresh.

name: Oklahoma
description: Located in the heart of Manchester's Norther Quarter, Oklahoma is home to an unapologetically bright and bold collection. Inspired by the vibrant cultures of Mexico, India and Morocco, founder Nicola Payne decided to make a move from London to open her boutique almost 25 years ago, planting roots in the cosmopolitan city of Manchester where she was born and bred. As Manchester and its surrounding areas has regenerated, Oklahoma has developed and evolved alongside.
founder_quote: "I have always been inspired by people who work with their hands and lead bright, colourful lives. Oklahoma is a reflection of this, years of hard work culminating in an Aladdin's cave full of unusual and surprising discoveries."

name: Frau Tonis Parfum
description: Inspired by the clear, delicate scents that her grandmother wore, Stefanie Hanssen decided to open her perfume boutique Frau Tonis in 2009. The idea was simple - to create pure scents that would inspire the wearer and evoke positive feelings and memories. Alongside their 36 signature fragrances, the shop hosts olfactory workshops where perfume enthusiasts can create bespoke scents.
founder_quote: "Bespoke perfume" is a strong trend and we believe that more suppliers will enter the market in the future. Creating something new and finding something individual - that's what drives us!

name: Vitamin
description: After spending a decade doing design work all over the world, brothers Chris and Andy Vernall felt that a fraternal collaboration should be their next venture. In 2004 they launched Vitamin, a brand that enabled them to design and manufacture their own product range. Fast forward to 2017 and the pair decided to open a retail space off their studio in Hoxton, where customers could experience their products in the flesh.
founder_quote: "We’re inspired by materials, interesting manufacture processes both traditional and new, and (of course) each other!"

name: Moeon
description: Founder Sonja Lotz has always owned shops, before opening Moeon in Kreuzberg, Berlin she ran another fashion boutique but, when that closed and she had her children, her attention turned to the world of sustainable fashion and how fast fashion is polluting our environment. From organic cotton, to tencel, to vegetable tanned leather, each piece has been made sustainably and sourced from labels around the world.

founder_quote: If you want a truly beautiful hat you go to a milliner like Philip Treacy. If you want incredible shoes you go to Christian Louboutin. If you want glasses that are amazing quality and that are unique and timeless in their design, then it has to be an OG frame.
name: Oliver Goldsmith Store.LDN
description: Since 1926, Oliver Goldsmith has been creating eyewear that pushes the boundaries of expectation and self-expression. The Goldsmith name became synonymous with celebrity and style in the last half of the 20th century. Michael Caine, Audrey Hepburn, Grace Kelly, Peter Sellers, models on the catwalks of Givenchy and Dior – all could be spotted in iconic OG frames. Today, Claire, a fourth-generation Goldsmith, carries on the tradition by recreating classic models from the archive and designing innovative new styles inspired by the family’s legacy. OG Store.LDN is the only place where you can see the collections in their entirety as well as browse the extensive vintage OG archive.

name: Olive Loves Alfie
description: When Olive Loves Alfie founder Ashlyn lost her job in fashion and gave birth to her baby daughter, she decided to draw on both of those experiences to start her own childrenswear boutique. Within 6 weeks she had opened a shop space in Stoke Newington, becoming one of the very first bricks-and-mortar shops in the UK to champion up-and-coming Scandi children's labels.
founder_quote: "Having worked in the fashion industry I was aware of the inbuilt environmental and social issues and wanted to be part of the movement for change, so I decided to create a store that worked with brands who care about these problems."

description:
The women's luxury jeans destination stocking hand-picked cult brands.  A denim-only concept store. 
"McQuinn stocks the big premium labels as well as vintage styles that she sources herself. Deliberately 'self-service' and with a personal, customer-centered approach, the store takes the confusion out of buying denim by paring back the rhetoric and focusing on the one unifying element." - Vogue.com
founder_quote:
The denim-only den of your dreams.

We stock a carefully selected edit of the best women's jeans from around the world.
name: Bad Denim
Maerz
description: Martin Baumgartner, the founder of Maerz, previously worked for high-end fashion brands in Berlin's department stores before opening Maerz in the heart of Friedrichshain. Stocking women's and men's fashion, Martin mixes classic design with more daring pieces which change seasonally. His fashion connections and expertise have made him an important person in Berlin's fashion scene.

name: Couverture & The Garbstore
description: Set across three levels in a converted townhouse in the heart of Notting Hill, Couverture & The Garbstore offers a stunning collection of clothing and accessories sourced by owners Emily Dyson and Ian Paley. Moving between floors, customers are transported through a refined collection of menswear, womenswear, accessories and homeware, and can discover the story behind each label as they go. The team champion emerging talent and independent brands and are constantly evolving their range to offer the most exciting and intriguing collections possible.
founder_quote: "Since our launch, we have continually focused on supporting emerging and independent brands and designers, it’s become the backbone to what we stand for.”

name: Collection & Co
description: Felesha Papa began her career in the fashion industry, where she quickly noticed the growing demand for ethical, non-leather footwear. She decided to launch her own shoe collection that combined contemporary design and veganism, which she now sells in her boutique Collection & Co in Broadmead.
founder_quote: We live in a society that is becoming increasingly conscious of the environment. I feel that we can help people make a difference when they shop.

name: A.D.Deertz
description: With its striking illuminated facade, it's hard to miss Berlin clothing boutique A.D. Deertz. Owner Wibke's focus is on sustainability and autonomy; she travels frequently to all four corners of the world to seek inspiration, design new items, and carefully source fabrics. In-store Wibke keeps her designs in stock for as long as there is demand for the product, which enables her to adapt and respond fully to her customers' needs.
founder_quote: My idea of smart consumption is to buy less and select well. Because of this, our focus is simple and individual classics made of high-quality fabrics with a beautiful feel.

name: Smallprint Books
description: Inspired by the idea that children's books should be beautiful to look at as well as to read, Jenny Thomas decided to set up her own bookshop in London's Forest Hill. Since opening the shop space has become a local community hub, and plays host to regular story readings, kids' craft sessions and workshops. Each product in the store has been lovingly chosen by Jenny herself, who doesn't stock a single book that she hasn't read cover to cover.
founder_quote: "I make it a mission to read and understand each book I stock; it helps me offer really personal service to everyone who needs it."

name: Harper Kids
description: Portuguese native Fernanda Janeiro is the brains behind Newbury boutique Harper Kids, which specialises in baby and children's clothes. Each item is produced in Europe under Fernanda's close inspection - she works hard to source ethically conscious fabrics and often visits her manufacturers to oversee the production processes.
founder_quote: "I try to encourage my customers to follow the mantra of "buy less, choose well, make it last". It's better to spend a little bit more but be sure of how and where the item was made."

name: Petticoat Lane
description: Just a stone's throw away from the pastel coloured buildings of the Llandudno promenade, you'll find lifestyle shop Petticoat Lane founded by Llandudno-native Kate Russell. Kate feels passionate about the concept of “thoughtful buying”; encouraging shoppers to consider the purpose behind the purchase. The shop gives customers the products with which they can create comfortable and aesthetically-pleasing spaces in their home and offers clothing and accessories which shoppers can feel confident in.
founder_quote: "Opening a boutique of your own is a fascinating journey of creativity, and the last seven years have been exciting, unpredictable, wonderful and frightening in equal measure."

name: Sabrina Dehoff
description: Berlin boutique Sabrina Dehoff was founded by the eponymous designer as a space to showcase her distinctive jewellery designs. Housed in an airy modern building, the shop is located in the city's thriving gallery quarter. Sabrina sees her boutique as a space where visitors can come and immerse themselves in her brand by touching, trying on, and talking to her and her team.
founder_quote: Successful retail is not about online versus offline, but rather how to connect and create synergy between the two.

name: Lavender Room
description: In 2003, after years working in high street retail, Jenny and Nicky realised their shared dream of moving to the coast and opening their own independent boutique. Fast forward to the present day and the Lavender Room is a haven of serenity in the heart of Brighton, stocking a carefully curated range of clothing, accessories, jewellery, homewares, and gifts.
founder_quote: Brighton is full of creative people and independent businesses so inspiration is never far away!

name: Fundamental Berlin
description: When Stephen K Molloy and Gunnar Rönsch met during their architectural studies at the Universität der Künste in Berlin, it became abundantly clear that they shared a passion for intelligent design. They opened Fundamental Berlin in 2011, and haven't looked back since. Each product they sell is designed in line with the mathematical principles that underpin the natural world, making them true must-haves for fans of clever and beautiful homewares.
founder_quote: We look at patterns and forms that occur in the natural world; we adapt and play with them as a starting point for all of our designs.

name: Jennifer Kent
description: Nestled amongst the streets of Glasgow's creative West End, knitwear studio Jennifer Kent was founded by the eponymous Jennifer as a space to showcase her minimalist knits. All of her clothing is designed in the studio and produced in Scotland using only time-honoured manufacturing techniques. Visit her store and you'll also find a selection of carefully curated books, accessories, stationery and art by a range of creative talents.
founder_quote: "I think the future of retail will be about memorable, personalised experiences. I hope that customers leave my shop feeling inspired."

name: Alfie Douglas
description: Wander through the thriving streets of the Shoreditch Triangle and you'll find family-run boutique Alfie Douglas. Specialising in expertly crafted leather goods, the boutique was designed as a space where co-founders Simon, Davida, Emily and Jessica Hadden could engage with their local creative community. All of their products are designed and developed in-house, before being produced by skilled British manufacturers.
founder_quote: Our aim was to develop a brand that embodied our personal values. We wanted to create a beautiful space where customers could meet the designers and learn about the inspiration behind every piece.

name: Fable Interiors
description: Before opening Fable Interiors in Leamington Spa, founder Harriet Sinclair-Wilson worked in visual merchandising for Arcadia as well as roles in marketing and sales. This experience in retail and business helped her realise her passion to open her own boutique and in 2014 she opened Fable Interiors with her husband Nick. As the name suggests, Fable Interiors is based on telling the stories of the handmade and fair trade items they sell.
founder_quote: "Running an independent retail business is very personal, you get you know your customers well and they get to know you. It’s great when I stumble across a product that is completely different to anything else we have in the store and am able to tell my customers the story behind it."

description: With a background in buying and merchandising, founder Caroline Clifton wanted to transfer her retail experience into opening her own boutique. Present In The Laine was opened over three years ago in response to a gap in the Brighton market for a boutique selling a variety of quality products from multiple categories, including women's and men's accessories, specific gifting products and cards. Although the shop stocks many items for customers to treat themselves, Caroline is on a mission to help her customers find the perfect gift.
name: Present In The Laine
founder_quote: "We carefully select every product for our boutique with our customers in mind, only stocking things we really love. I am constantly inspired by my customers and the area of Brighton, there is such creativity and community here that is unusual on many high streets in the UK."

name: Starstyling
description: Katja Schlegel and Kai Seifried became friends in the early 1990s, and their subsequent relationship and decision to start a family is the cornerstone of their Berlin-based brand and boutique starstyling. Focused primarily on homewares and clothing, starstyling has become an integral part of the German fashion scene, and is widely recognised as an embodiment of Berlin's creative spirit.
founder_quote: The idea behind starstyling was to play with timeless classics, twisting them, adding colour, and topping them off with a good dose of humour.

name: Tonic
description: After getting his feet wet in the world of retail buying, Phil Bickley decided he wanted to open his own store where customers could discover quality products from all over the world in a laid-back store environment. Since the boutique opened on Portobello Road in 2000, Phil has taken great care to source products that he feels accurately reflect Tonic's core values of understated quality, subtle detail, value for money, and innovation.
founder_quote: "When I opened Tonic I decided I wanted to create a store that was more than just a clothes shop. It needed to sell great clothes but also be a place were people could come and feel comfortable, hang out, and put the world to rights."

name: The Forest & Co
description: After selling solely only for many years, the founder Elaine Leach was driven to open a bricks-and-mortar space by a desire to see her curated collection in context and to experiment with new displays and ranges. Elaine draws her inspiration from Denmark and their amazing ability to design and put things together. By combining Danish design with her love of dark colours in interiors, Elaine has created a unique shopping experience and product collection.

name: Type Hype
description: Based in the very centre of Berlin in an old printer's office, TYPE HYPE may well be the world's only lifestyle-store-meets-milk-bar. Owned by design aficionado Kirsten Dietz, the boutique stocks sustainably produced homewares and gifts emblazoned with the letters of the alphabet. And the milk? A tradition that started many years ago, when typesetting apprentices would drink a lot of milk whilst working on their creations.
founder_quote: "Our products are made for all those people who, in spite of living in the digital age, value tangible design, high-quality printed artwork, and supreme quality."

name: Mark + Fold
description: Self-confessed stationery addict Amy Cooper-Wright opened Mark+Fold in 2015 to give fellow fans an alternative to mass-market offerings. Having previously trained in bookbinding as well as working in art book design, Amy was well positioned to create beautiful notebooks that combined simplicity and quality. These pared-back books have earned Mark+Fold a dedicated following, and continue to sit at the heart of the Wood Green boutique.
founder_quote: "I think people are fed up with mass-production. We all want more connection with how and where things are made, and the story behind their making — this is really what inspired us to set up Mark+Fold."

name: Thornback & Peel
description:
The pair set up a studio in 2006 at Cockpit Arts and a year later established Thornback & Peel creating beautiful, intricate screen-printed pieces for the home. Their signature style borrows imagery that plays on artistic traditions, combining modernist geometric patterns with 19th century wood engravings.  Their work is a celebration of British humour and design.

Thornback & Peel’s stand-alone boutique opened on Rugby Street, London last year in the beautifully historic enclave of Bloomsbury. The collection comprises a range of illustrations inspired by flora and fauna hand-printed on napkins, tea towels, cushions, lampshades, furnishing fabrics and stationery.
founder_quote: Founded by Juliet Thornback and Delia Peel, Thornback & Peel is a quintessential British brand renowned for its modern interpretation of heritage motifs and design.

description: The Keep is a stylish independent boutique full of carefully curated sustainable fashion and homewares located in the heart of Brixton Village. Through careful curation the customer is presented with the best that brands have to offer, inspiring them to buy clothes to treasure and keep. Founded by Kate Richards, the vision was to create a one-stop shop stocked with the best in ethical, stylish clothing. With its sustainable focus and a push for transparency, The Keep lets customers in on the story behind the brands.
founder_quote: The Keep is a stylish independent boutique full of carefully curated sustainable fashion and homeware located in the heart of Brixton Village. Through careful curation the customer is presented with the best that brands have to offer, inspiring them to buy clothes to treasure and keep.
name: The Keep

description: Starting life online, Ross & Brown became a bricks-and-mortar space in 2015, basing itself in Cheam Village on the London outskirts. Founded by Peter Ross and Gary Brown, they have combined their extensive experience in commercial interior design alongside a passion for Nordic design. Ross & Brown boutique is home to stylish, design-led homeware and accessories to add a Scandi statement to any home.
name: Ross & Brown
founder_quote: "We never meant to set up a Scandi boutique but everything seemed to fall into place and before we knew the Scandinavian obsession took hold. I like to think we were advocates at the start of its resurgence in the UK."

"I think people are really enjoying shopping in actual shops again. Of course online shopping is major business and a great way to reach customers all over the world, but there is nothing better than face to face interaction. It also encourages us all to be more considered in our purchases and allows the high street to become a more interesting place."
description: Home & Kids in Blackheath was founded by mum of four Maritza Masiello, who was looking to take on a new challenge after a successful career in legal accounting. Originally a children's boutique opened with a business partner, Maritza has since continued the business on her own, rebranding to include products that focus on the home and family. As well as stocking a range of beautiful products and gifts, the boutique is also home to a cafe, allowing customers to enjoy a coffee whilst browsing.
name: Home & Kids

description: Womenswear boutique Charli was launched in 2008 with the intention of offering a collection of carefully-designed essentials for the contemporary shopper. Each item in their Muswell Hill and Hampstead shops captures a sense of effortless elegance, with a core range of directional designs in natural fabrics taking centre stage.
founder_quote: "At Charli we pride ourselves on our innovative take on traditional techniques; we feel they truly encapsulate the energy of the London fashion scene."
name: Charli
Triangle Store
description: East London's Triangle Store was established by three friends, Matt, Mary and Tory, whose aim was to combine their passion for mid-century furniture and homewares in a shop full of things they love. Over the years the store has grown to include collections from independent designers, established design and accessory companies and vintage pieces sourced from all over Europe. Discover a wealth of lifestyle products from jewellery to clothing and homewares, set in a beautiful two-storey space.
founder_quote: "The best thing about Triangle is that it represents a very personal passion for simple, useful and beautiful design. Triangle is based around the principle that if it’s in the shop, it’s pretty much guaranteed to be in at least one of the three founders’ homes."

name: Burrows And Hare
description: Burrows and Hare founder Junaid Ansari grew up around menswear fashion and retail, deciding to open his own store after seeing a gap in the Oxfordshire market. By curating a collection of timeless, high quality pieces, it has become a real destination for the discerning gentleman with an interest in craftsmanship as well as classic style. Alongside branded products, Burrows and Hare also stock their own collection, which is made in the UK and sourced from the best mills in the country.
founder_quote: "I wanted to be able to offer our customer a variety of high quality goods that you often don't find in stores, focusing on expert craftmanship and materials rather than specific trends. Our philosophy is to encourage people to buy less and to invest in better quality."

name: Jovonna London
description: Carrying on the legacy of her mother and grandmother making and designing clothes, founder Jojo Yan Jiao, established her own label, Jovonna in 2007 after completing an International Business degree. With a focus on contemporary style, Jovonna's range is for the fashion-forward woman in search of clothing not everyone will have.

name: Sue Parkinson
description: Sue Parkinson was established in 1973 in the beautiful Cotswold village of Broadway. Still family-run after nearly 40 years, the boutique continues to provide a unique blend of clothing, homewares, fragrance and body products set in beautiful historic buildings in the Cotswolds.

name: House By Betty
description: After graduating with a degree in fashion design, founder Lauren Treharne decided to take on the challenge of opening her own boutique and follow her passion for interiors. With a desire to create a space for customers to discover and browse everything from hand-stitched Viennese rugs through to coffee beans, House by Betty is an emporium of homewares and household products. Following a childhood living with her grandparents, Lauren was inspired by their ethos for lifelong quality in product and strives to stock only the best, championing the traditional methods and makers.
founder_quote: "The little independent boutiques, creative hubs and coffee shops are run by people from so many different backgrounds, my favourite thing is getting to know these places and the wonderful people who have created them. We work to provide an exciting environment for customers in an innovating and contemporary retail space, inspired by the people in our community."

name: Artisans and Adventurers
description: Artisans & Adventurers, located on Columbia Road in vibrant East London, was founded by accessories designer Amy Fleuriot and craft development expert Bee Friedmann who discovered a common love for design and sustainability after meeting whilst dog walking. Artisans & Adventurers gives traditional craft modern appeal by combining a minimalist aesthetic with a love of colour and print. The boutique features a range of handmade jewellery, designed in house in collaboration with artisan producers in Kenya, handwoven textiles and traditional African fabrics and designs. From chocolate to cushions and woven baskets, A&A's goal is to bring a little bit of joy to everyday objects.
founder_quote: "The nature of the global supply chain means our decisions as consumers affect people all around the world. We strive to source products which bring as much joy to their creator as they do to the customer."

name: items of note
description: items of note is a modern gift shop, with several residencies throughout London. An item of note means a product of integrity as well as style, and the collection is hand selected from independent designers, artists and small scale companies around the world. The edit is tailored to each location, with a focus on gifts, books, stationery, art, ceramics, accessories and homeware with a contemporary aesthetic, including many special commissions and exclusive collaborations.
founder_quote: “We get heart swells when we come across really good things made with passion and soul, by people who are emotionally engaged in what they do. We believe everyone can find happiness in an item of note.”

name: Botanique
description: Founded by Alice and filled with handmade treasures and plants, Botanique Workshop offers a space to browse and relax in the heart of London. Having come up with her business plan whilst sailing mid Atlantic as a sail boat skipper, Alice opened her boutique to offer customers an array of unique crafts made and inspired by materials found at flea markets. A self-taught shop keeper, Alice has developed the business over the years, incorporating a flower arranging service which is run by Pip and expanding the range of products on offer. The diverse range includes plants, jewellery, stationary, sewn accessories and homewares and 60% are made in house. Staff love to share their skills with customers and can often be found making products on the shop floor.
founder_quote: “People will always shop offline, but we bricks and mortar shops have got to be smart in how we pitch ourselves: it's all about experiences, whether that be excellent customer service, making a community around your brand, or selling a product that you simply cant find elsewhere.”

name: Quill London
description: Several years ago, Quill London founder Lucy Edmonds spotted a trend for beautiful modern calligraphy in the USA, and wondered why it hadn't yet made its way to the UK. So she decided to combine her thriving stationery business with London's first modern calligraphy workshop, and now runs the two seamlessly side-by-side from her boutique in Clerkenwell.
founder_quote: "I hope that people leave us feeling satisfied that they've found what they were looking for, perhaps even found an unexpected treat, and above all else, had a great, personal experience. "

name: Lift Store
description: The aptly named Lift Store in Southwold is an uplifting space, filled to the brim with colourful gifts and accessories. Founder David opened the store as a space where he could sell beautiful items handmade by his mum Anne; items that he felt would bring a smile to people's faces. As well as spreading joy to his customers, David also likes to give back to his community - every 200th customer who shops at the store will receive £5 to spend on a charity initiative of their choice.
founder_quote: "I think that people will always love buying something new and exciting, and while it's probably true that stuff doesn't make you happy, it's also true that being surrounded by nice, well designed things can lift you up!"

name: Hill & Friends
description: Perfectly positioned in between the old luxury of Bond Street and the cosmopolitan airs of Oxford Street, Hill & Friends in Mayfair wholly encapsulates the quirky charm of the London fashion scene. Founded by Emma Hill and Georgia Fendley, whose previous experience includes years at the helm of brands like Mulberry, Marc Jacobs, and Gap, the boutique is home to an eye-catching range of luxury leather bags.
founder_quote: "It's important to us that our sourcing is ethical, that we treat our customers as friends, and that we create beautiful product that makes our customers smile."

name: Born Store
description: Founded by retail veteran Simon Porter in 2017, Born Store is a curated menswear and lifestyle store in the heart of the coastal town of Eastbourne. The boutique's primary focus is contemporary clothing and accessories that are underpinned by a timeless, relaxed aesthetic rather than fast-moving trends. Simon takes great care in curating his range, sourcing both established and up-and-coming brands from the four corners of the globe.
founder_quote: "All of our products are chosen because of their quality and character. We hope people leave the store feeling like they've bought something they'll value for a long time."

name: Das Goodshaus
description: Once they had recognised their shared passion for interior design, it was a natural choice for Joseph and Lucie to open Das Goodshaus, an eclectic boutique focused on beautiful, functional homewares. The aim was to create an inspirational space where customers could find unique treasures that they wouldn't find anywhere else, such as retro kitchenware from Japan or vintage carpets from Tunisia.
founder_quote: "We believe that there will be an even bigger gap between online and bricks-and-mortar shops in the future, but also that more people will consciously decide to shop local."

name: The Gilded Teapot
description: The Gilded Teapot is a speciality tea and coffee boutique located in Lymington and founded by tea-lover Jo. A celebration of craftsmanship, provenance and exploration, the boutique is filled with the finest tea leaves from across the globe, all carefully sourced by Jo. As well as ensuring exceptional brews, this dedication to sustainability helps to support a number of independent organic tea growers and local craftspeople in countries all over the world.
founder_quote: "Sales for loose leaf tea have been going up year on year. People aren't spending a lot of money on going out or holidays but they're treating themselves to luxury basics like loose leaf tea instead."
